This BioSample is a metagenomic assembly obtained from the human urinary tract metagenome BioSamples: SAMN18524249, SAMN18524250, SAMN18524251, SAMN18524252, SAMN18524253, SAMN18524254, SAMN18524255, SAMN18524256, SAMN18524257, and SAMN18524258
Department of Disease Control, Ministry of Public Health
Isolated from the gastrointestinal tract of Cyprinus carpio
Biomass centrifuged 10 min 10,000xg, aliquot frozen for DNA extraction
Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics

The gut microbiota has been typically viewed as an environmental factor for human health. Twins are well suited for investigating the concordance of their gut microbiomes and decomposing genetic and environmental influences. However, existing twin studies utilizing metagenomic shotgun sequencing have included only a few samples. Here, we sequenced fecal samples from 250 adult twins in the TwinsUK registry and constructed a comprehensive gut microbial reference gene catalog. We demonstrate heritability of many microbial taxa and functional modules in the gut microbiome, including those associated with diseases. Moreover, we identified 8 million SNPs in the gut microbiome and observe a high similarity in microbiome SNPs between twins that slowly decreases after decades of living apart. The results shed new light on the genetic and environmental influences on the composition and function of the gut microbiome that could relate to risk of complex diseases.
Bioinformatics Core Facility of Ifremer (French Research Institute for Exploitation of the Sea)
bacterial strain isolated from fresh salmon

Raw data were obtained by sequencing on a MinIOn MK1C DNA extracts from bacterial isolates. Library was prepared using Rapid Barcoding sequencing kit.Demultiplexing of the fast5 files was conducted with Guppy v6.1.1.
Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics
MaxBin2, MetaBat2, Concoct with default parameter of the metaWRAP pipeline. Bin refinement module used from metaWRAP with default parameters.

INSPIRE is a study of duodenal mucosal resurfacing, through intestinal ablation, to investigate its potential for treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. In this study, the microbiome before and after intestinal ablation was studied in combination with a range of clinical markers.

The taxonomy of this Metagenome-Assembled Genome was originally computed with GTDBtk, which assigned the following taxonomic annotation: d__Bacteria;p__Proteobacteria;c__Gammaproteobacteria;o__Enterobacterales;f__Hafniaceae;g__Hafnia;s__Hafnia paralvei
Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics
MaxBin2, MetaBat2, Concoct with default parameter of the metaWRAP pipeline. Bin refinement module used from metaWRAP with default parameters.

Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an effective therapy for recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). However, the overall mechanisms of FMT have not been comprehensively elucidated, and the safety of FMT has recently become a serious concern because of the occurrence of drug-resistant bacteremia transmitted by FMT. We investigated whether the functional restoration of the bacteriomes and viromes by FMT could be an indicator of successful FMT.

Parkinson's disease has been improved to association with gastrointestinal symptoms and gut microbiota disorders, probiotics is considered as a technique for GI symptoms, while the regulative effect of probiotics on Parkinson's disease is limited. The supplementary treatment of Probio-M8 on Parkinson has been investigation.

Antibiotic overuse has promoted the spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) with significant health and economic consequences. Surveillance of resistance reservoirs, like the rarely explored oral microbiome, is necessary to combat AMR. We characterised the development of the paediatric oral resistome and investigated its role in dental caries in 221 twin children sampled over the first decade of life. From 535 oral metagenomes, we identified 309 antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs), which significantly clustered by age, with the influence of host genetics on antimicrobial resistance increasing over time. Our results suggest the mobilisation potential of ARGs increased with age as Tn916 transposase was co-located with more species and ARGs as children grew. Dental caries compared to health was associated with a depletion of ARGs and species, which was reversed when restored. Our results highlight the dynamic nature of the paediatric oral resistome, and its potential role in transmission of AMR and dysbiosis.

The taxonomy of this Metagenome-Assembled Genome was originally computed with GTDBtk, which assigned the following taxonomic annotation: d__Bacteria;p__Proteobacteria;c__Gammaproteobacteria;o__Enterobacterales;f__Hafniaceae;g__Hafnia;s__Hafnia paralvei
